talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Vanstone representing the Attorney-General. Minister, are you aware that, as this government insists on careering down the path of outsourcing core Commonwealth services, the appeal, review and access to information rights of every Australian are being radically diminished? Do you agree that those Australians who receive Commonwealth services through a private contractor will no longer have a right to access their own private information held by a contractor through freedom of information laws? Do you also agree that, because clients are not party to contracts between the Commonwealth agency and the service provider, any access or review provisions in the contract are worthless because clients will have no standing to take legal action if their rights are breached?

—I thank Senator Jacinta Collins for that question. Senator Collins, you ask generally about the principles of contracting out and how that relates to privacy and then you ask some specific questions. The situation is this: the government does recognise the importance of protecting individual privacy and providing access to documents under the Freedom of Information Act. Any steps to contract out government functions will take into account the importance of protecting privacy and providing access to documents under the Freedom of Information Act. Senator, you were not here at the time but, regrettably, when we were in opposition Senator Patterson and some other senators had to pursue your government time after time when it failed to protect the privacy of social security recipients, for example. I think it was Senator Patterson, if I recall correctly, who pursued your government in relation to social security recipients' information in the gutters of some suburb of Melbourne. And you have the cheek to come in here and ask this question! You have no corporate memory. It may be, Senator Collins, that you have no memory at all. In any event, plenty of Australians do.

answer.para: The government has decided that the Privacy Act will be extended to all contractors who hold personal information on behalf of the government. In order to give practical effect to that decision, the government has decided that the Freedom of Information Act will be extended to apply to requests by individuals for access to and correction of personal information about themselves held by contractors on behalf of the government.

It is worth adding, speaking generally, that in a range of contracts entered into by the government there is a clause which allows the government to opt out of the contract. As I recall, that is certainly the case in relation to the employment services contracts. The contract can be terminated. That was one of the complaints that the then Australian Democrat, now the earth moves Labor Party member, raised with us. You raise, perhaps inadvertently, one of the very positive aspects of those contracts—there was planned to be the opportunity to opt out. If someone does not adequately protect privacy that would no doubt be an option that would be taken.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, do you agree with the Administrative Review Council view that contracting out of services raises the potential for a loss of accountability in relation to both the services provided to individual recipients and the broader questions of public interest, such as the evaluation of the performance of contractors? Or is this loss of accountability seen by this cynical government as an advantage of outsourcing?

—Senator Collins, I do not know whether you woke up and had a bucket of nails for breakfast. You cannot resist trying to put the barb in there somewhere. It does seem, Senator, as though you can see no good in this government. The fact that this government was elected by a vast majority of Australians ought to indicate to you that if you can see no good in this government you are at odds with the majority of the Australian community.

answer.para: It is not for me to agree or disagree with the report. I will refer that matter to the Attorney and if he cares to add to the answer I have given you, he will. But I think the answer was pretty clear. You may have wanted a different one but the answer is clear: this government will protect the privacy of people in contracting out through the contracts. That has been made very clear, Senator. If you do not understand contract law, go and get yourself a little advice.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer. Minister, ATSIC, the peak body representing Aboriginal people, has acknowledged that native title, in particular the right to negotiate clause, has all but crippled the mining industry. What impact has it had on the gold mining industry and what will be the effects if those opposite persist in preventing the passage of the whole of the government's 10-point Wik legislation?

—I thank Senator Lightfoot for his question. I convened a gold round table last month to discuss ways in which government and industry could work together to improve the competitiveness of the goldmining industry and production in Australia. I might remind senators that it is the second largest export industry in this country. Some 85 delegates attended, representing not only goldmining companies but also suppliers and marketers, the scientific community, industry associations and state governments. Some very positive suggestions were raised which will be followed up by a high level group which I will chair.

answer.para: Do you know what the major problem raised by the industry was? The No. 1 problem was Wik and native title, and I point out that the other issue was the outdated and inefficient taxation system—both legacies of 13 years of Labor mismanagement and their total capitulation to the very vocal left wing lobby group in this country. Will they ever learn?

I have waited in vain for some positive input from the shadow minister, Mr Stephen Smith. Mr Stephen Smith knows what the real problems are. He went to Kalgoorlie with his weak leader, Mr Beazley. Senator Crane and I were there at the time with the diggers and dealers, and do you know what they told us? They said that they were relaxed. They were relaxed because Mr Beazley and Mr Smith had assured them that they would support the coalition's amendments on native title in respect of mining. What happened afterwards? The loopy Left took over and rolled their weak leader. Mr Beazley knows that some 2,000 mining leases in his home state are bogged down for who knows how long under Labor's native title mess. The story is repeated in Queensland.
Those opposite should have a look at what ATSIC itself says about the current process. I quote:

. . . there are too many overlapping claims, requiring the limited resources of the Native Title Representative Body . . . and the Tribunal to be consumed by mediating intra-indigenous disputes rather than mediating claims. The major problem areas are the WA Goldfields, where of all claims, a total of 42 overlap, WA's Pilbara region, the north-east part of South Australia, north-west NSW, most of western Queensland and even the ACT.
The ATSIC report also adds:

The fact is that mining leases are being held up in the Right to Negotiate process—in WA alone some 1,913 out of the 2,094 tenements submitted to the process remain subject to negotiation. Furthermore, the rate of objection by native title parties to the grant of exploration licences is starting to increase significantly which will mean further delays.

It is clear that the Labor Party is making a desperate effort to mollify the industry. It is even clearer that the industry sees right through them. The Association of Mining and Exploration Companies said last month:

The ALP appears to have deserted its traditional support base—that is, Australian workers—in favour of the chattering classes. The ALP blithely pursues its outdated and irrelevant social policies most of which have proven worthless and in the end affect one person more than anyone else—the average worker.
They go on to state:
As every little Aussie battler knows, you go broke if you spend more than you can earn, a lesson the ALP has yet to learn.
The Labor Party would do well to listen to the Aussie battlers, rather than being hooked into the chattering classes.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Hill representing the Prime Minister. In light of this government's wholesale transfer of central Commonwealth government responsibilities and services to the private sector through outsourcing, contracting and corporatisation, can the minister inform the Senate whether there are any Commonwealth services which are too important in the lives of all Australians to be transferred to the vagaries of the market? Clearly you do not believe that labour market, social security or occupational rehabilitation services, for example, are sufficient matters to be core Commonwealth responsibilities. Or is it the case that, as with election promises, this government just fundamentally misunderstands what core responsibilities actually mean to ordinary Australians?

—The honourable senator could ask that question of her former leader, Mr Keating, who was one who drove this process forward when he was Labor Prime Minister of this country. He recognised that there were some services of government that could be more efficiently provided in terms of quality of output and from a cost point of view through the non-government sector. It was probably one of the few things that Mr Keating got right because there are some areas of service, and these matters are evolving as our economy evolves and as we face new elements of competition.

answer.para: One used to say that about such services as electricity provision in this country. The honourable senator could take that to Mr Carr and suggest to him that he has got it all wrong when he believes that electricity could be better provided by the non-government sector in New South Wales. The facts of life are that what was provided by government in the past may not be as effectively or efficiently provided by government in the future. Governments have to make a judgment as to how they can best deliver the services of government in a cost effective and efficient way.

This government has addressed that issue in relation to the challenges before it, and it has seen opportunities in outsourcing, for example, as the honourable senator says. It has seen opportunities in privatisation. I think you will see much more efficient airports, for example, in the future in this country. Services will be delivered more effectively. I think history will show that the efforts we have made to bring the private sector within the labour market in the provision of employment services will be recorded as one of the great triumphs of this government. To provide real competition in the service of providing jobs to those who aspire to jobs I think will be a great achievement and will more effectively address the needs of the unemployed of this country. We do not shy away from making the judgement that in certain circumstances we believe that services could be better provided through non-government avenues. Where we think they can be provided more effectively, efficiently and cost effectively, in particular, we will do so.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and it relates to the Natural Heritage Trust. In the coalition government's revegetation program, how critical is it to provide landowners and community groups with access to banks of native seeds? What is the government doing to overcome the longstanding deficiency in Australia's natural resource management?

—It is good to get a serious question on the Natural Heritage Trust. And it is true that in the revegetation of Australia, which is the principal purpose of the bushcare part of the Natural Heritage Trust, there has been a shortage of seed banks and there has been a shortage of good information for landowners and community groups in order to maximise their seed growing potential.

answer.para: The government, through the bushcare program, is pleased to be able to support the development of a network of regional seed banks in Australia. We are supporting in this coming year some two banks in Western Australia, two in Queensland, one in Tasmania, five in New South Wales and one in Victoria. These seed banks will collect the seed of native trees, shrubs, herbs and grasses locally, where possible, and from seed orchards. Seed will then be stored under ideal conditions and distributed at optimal times for direct seeding and the raising of seedlings.

This very important initiative will be complemented by better information. I make reference in particular to Flora bank—which is a project of the Australian National Botanic Gardens, CSIRO, Greening Australia and the Australian Tree Seed Centre—which will be able to provide to the community the best possible information on access to this genetic material, up-to-date information on the best plants to use in particular locations, revegetation techniques, and so on. These initiatives will better equip Australians to meet this enormous challenge of revegetating Australia, and it is an excellent initiative under the Natural Heritage Trust.

Contrast that constructive approach of this government with that of the Labor Party, which is determined to wreck the Natural Heritage Trust. I have to say that those who read the Age over the weekend might have reflected on its attempts to destroy the Woodhouse Pastoral Company's contribution. They might have, in particular, noted the comment of Dr Brian Whelan of the Trust for Nature, Victoria, who said of that particular investment:
For the investment of $52,900 not only the state—
of Victoria—
but also Australia has protected this prime area of box forest in perpetuity. It was a fantastic deal. To buy that land on the edge of Melbourne would have cost us millions.
That was the view of the conservation movement; that was their endorsement of this particular initiative.

Of course, what was said—and Senator Carr said it here the other day—was that the Labor Party does not support the concept of supporting conservation values on private land. But what Senator Carr should have done was refer to his own party policy. If he had read the platform released late last year, he would have seen that it said, `Labor is committed to off-reserve conservation programs developed in partnership with land-holders to ensure our native plants and animal habitats are maintained.'

So what this government did in relation to the Woodhouse Pastoral Company, in actual fact, was exactly what the Labor Party said should be done. Of course, the difference here was the name `Baillieu'. Once you saw the name Baillieu, that was the end of the issue; all you could say was `political rort'.
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Carr.
—It is about time the Labor Party, and in particular Senator Faulkner, apologised to the Baillieu family for defaming the living and defaming the dead. Perhaps after that apology—

answer.para: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Just a little bit of leadership, Senator. After that apology, you might follow your own party platform and endorse these programs of conserving these important natural values on private land as well as public land.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister have further information that he could give to the Senate on the proportion—
—Order! I would like to hear the question.
—Does the minister have further information on the proportion of funds allocated to the bushcare projects?

—I must say—particularly as a result of the useful question of Senator West, which was probably the best question to come from the Labor Party—I did get some further calculations made. One of the most interesting was that, in fact, as a result of my so-called intervention in the New South Wales projects, projects in Labor Party seats actually got more money than was recommended to me by the New South Wales Labor government.
—Ha, ha!

—But never let that get in the way of the chance of a political point. The other interesting statistics that have come out of this research—which do not surprise me because it was exactly what was intended—are that, as a result of that intervention also, when we look over the bushcare programs as a whole, more money went to community grants than was recommended. So more went to community grants, and less to state agencies; and more money went to capital works on the ground, and less to monitoring, inventory, investigations, et cetera. So, in actual fact, we are achieving exactly what we pledged. We are getting the money where we need it, projects on the ground. That is what was designed and that is what is occurring. (Time expired)
—My question is addressed to Senator Kemp representing the Minister for Finance. Is the minister aware of the recent report produced by Deloitte & Touche Consulting which states:

question.para: A whopping 60 per cent of public sector organisations that outsource IT functions do not achieve any cost savings, nearly twice the rate of the private sector.

If this is the case, why should we believe that the government will achieve the $1 billion savings figure it claims for IT outsourcing? Can the government produce an authoritative study of outsourcing that supports its cost saving claims?

talk.start.para: —As Senator Sherry will be aware, this government has pursued an outsourcing policy in relation to IT. I might say, the genesis of that policy, the basis of it, Senator Sherry, actually lay in the previous government. You would be aware of reports, which I do not happen to have here at the moment, but I daresay I could bring them down to the chamber—

answer.para: Senator Lundy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Do not get sensitive, Senator Lundy. As I was saying, there are reports released by the former government which stressed the importance of outsourcing. In fact, the former government, of which you were a member, Senator Sherry, made some very important initiatives in this area. Only with the advent of this government did Senator Lundy discover that outsourcing was not appropriate. I must say that in a sense I was pleased that the Senator Lundy view of the world did not prevail at the ALP national conference. Senator Lundy, correct me if I am wrong, but it struck me on my reading of the motions that the national conference did give some endorsement to IT outsourcing.

answer.para: Senator Sherry, I do not know whether you have been at the estimates hearings but there have been very extensive debates—in fact, hugely extensive. Senator Lundy has trawled over every conceivable area and has run down every path in order to try to buttress a policy which her own party does not accept.

We have been delighted that Mr Fahey, as I think you will be aware, has announced cluster 3. The savings in that cluster are very extensive. That has been reported, Senator Sherry. Let me make it clear that this government makes no apology for outsourcing IT. We regard it as a good policy, just as your government regarded it as a good policy—and, I might say, as your national conference motions regarded it as a good policy. As I said, we are moving very firmly and very strongly down this road of IT outsourcing. Senator Sherry, if you are going to adopt the Senator Lundy position, that is interesting, but I have to say that that has not been your previous style on these matters.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, my question went to Deloitte & Touche Consulting, which you failed to address totally. Going back to that issue, is it the case that this study was reported in the Australian Financial Review on 16 December 1997 and the minister's office demanded a meeting with the two Deloitte & Touche staff and pressured them to take action to counter the impression given by the newspaper story? Was the letter from Dr Lisle-Williams published in the Financial Review on 17 December provided to or cleared with the minister's office before being submitted for publication? Was an existing contract between Deloitte & Touche and the Department of Finance and Adminis tration used to pressure the firm to publish this letter? How can you justify this action?

—There are a whole host of assumptions in that question—none of which you are able to demonstrate. You have asked me about what Mr Fahey did. What I shall do, as you would expect, is refer your question to Mr Fahey and see whether he wishes to provide any further information to you.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. I refer the minister to his discussion paper on reform of Commonwealth environmental legislation. This paper indicates that provisions in the new biodiversity act will completely replace the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. The minister will be aware that rain forest logging in the Daintree and Wet Tropics and development at the Hinchinbrook Channel and at the Franklin Dam are held back only by virtue of proclamations under that act. The minister will also be aware that state governments want those proclamations to be lifted. Can the minister give a categorical assurance to the Australian public right now that the existing proclamations under that act will be remade under the new act to protect those places forever?

—That really will be something that the Australian Democrats will be able to contribute to when we get to the legislative phase of this project. By way of background, I think everyone agrees that the Commonwealth government's environment law is outdated. It should have been updated years ago, but, of course, we had 13 years of a Labor government that had no interest in these matters. The concept of biodiversity has been introduced; national strategies on biodiversity have been agreed to between the Commonwealth and states; and there have been national strategies on ecologically sustainable development. None of these concepts were really brought within contemporary environmental law.

answer.para: We have picked up the challenge and started a process of evaluation and negotiation with the states as to what could comprise a new and better mix of environmental laws, Commonwealth and state, to better achieve the best environmental outcomes for our nation. We reached a situation of agreement in principle at the last COAG meeting towards the end of last year on what the best mix of roles and responsibilities would be.

As a result of that, we have built on that agreement and produced a consultation paper, which I released a week or two ago, which looks at our preferred option for legislative implementation. First, there will be a new environmental protection act. Second, as the honourable senator says, for the first time there will be a biodiversity act. Third, and ultimately, there will be a new heritage act to update the provisions of the Australian Heritage Commission legislation. The biodiversity act, which the honourable senator alludes to, will better be able to protect such values as world heritage and other values which we describe within the context of national environmental significance. That is going to be the goal of the legislation in that regard.

You would be aware also of the deficiencies in the existing world heritage legislation. It does not, for example, trigger our environmental protection legislation at all—the EP(IP) legislation—which has caused the need for these proclamations in the past. The need may well be overtaken by the act itself being the primary trigger capacity for the new environmental protection act. So we may well be able to achieve—in fact, our goal is to achieve this—more effective outcomes and more direct outcomes, not indirect outcomes of the type that the honourable senator referred to, through legislation that is directly targeted at these particular needs.

The next stage, as I said, will be the drafting and introduction of this legislation into the parliament. I expect then that, within the Senate, it will go to the relevant Senate committee for further consideration and there will be debate on the details of that legislation. I would hope that before the end of this year we will have enacted through this parliament this contemporary environmental legislation which will bring us up to world's best standard. Certainly, in a vitally important area, we will have achieved something that the former Labor government in 13 years was not even prepared to attempt.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I think your answer was no. But let us get this clear, because I think we are having difficulty in believing that what your government does is in the best interests of the environment. I ask you again: can you give us a cast-iron guarantee that under this act the Franklin cannot be dammed, that there can be no rainforest logging in the wet tropics and that the Hinchinbrook Channel cannot be ruined?

—This government is not going to dam the Franklin. This government is not going to reintroduce logging in the wet tropics. This government is actually acting to protect the conservation values of the Hinchinbrook Channel. As you know, that is why we are in the process of drafting a regional plan for the whole of that Hinchinbrook area in conjunction with the Queensland government. It is under the chairmanship of Dr Joe Baker. It will provide a regime to ensure that all future developments in that region are in fact compatible with the important conservation values which must be preserved.

answer.para: The senator can rest at ease. This government is taking its responsibility in this area seriously. It will ensure that these vitally important values are properly protected through the Commonwealth and through a more effective cooperative regime with each of the states.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Parer, the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the minister confirm the information he provided to Senator Faulkner in his answer to question on notice No. 817 that the primary industries and energy portfolio contracted the firm of Burson-Marstellar to `organise a sod-turning ceremony at the new Australian Geological Survey Organisation building site'? Can you also confirm that Burson-Marstellar was paid a total of $25,328 for this sod-turning ceremony and that the contract was not awarded following an open tender pro cess, supposedly because Burson-Marstellar had undertaken recent Commonwealth work of a similar nature? Which other sod-turning ceremonies, other than Senator Eric over there, has Burson-Marstellar been paid an outrageous amount of Commonwealth money to organise? How can you justify paying this ludicrous amount of money for a sod-turning ceremony without testing the market? Minister, did this money actually purchase—(Time expired)
—I am unaware of the detail of that particular contract to which you refer. I am not sure whether Senator Quirke is referring to the sod-turning ceremony or the opening of the AGSO building.
—Sod-turning.
—That was two years ago.
—How do you know?
—I was the one that put the shovel in the dirt two years ago.

answer.para: Senator Ian Macdonald interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I will take Senator Ian Macdonald's interjection and promise to speak in words of one syllable. I suspect that Senator Quirke is talking about the opening of the new building, but I will check on that. I am unaware of who was given the job of the opening.

answer.para: But let me say this: the opening of the AGSO building was a major feature in the Australian Capital Territory, notwithstanding the budget constraints we had when the decision was made just over two years ago to go ahead and build the AGSO building. It recognised the great contribution that is made by the Australian Geological Survey Organisation to the minerals industry in this country.

I might say that, notwithstanding invitations that were offered to people, as I understand it, on both sides of the chamber, the only one I can recall who was there was Senator Calvert. I know Senator Lundy was invited, but she did not show up.

talk.start.para: —Madam President was there.
—Madam President was there. The Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory, Kate Carnell, was also there.

answer.para: It was a big day not just for the members of parliament and AGSO but also for the staff of AGSO. I think the whole staff of AGSO were invited to that opening. It is, as everyone would be aware, very much a specialist building. It is also very much a state-of-the-art building; the heating and cooling of that building is carried out by geothermal methods. It is the biggest building, I think, in Australia—and I think it might have been said to be the biggest in the world—that actually uses geothermal type heating and cooling for the air conditioning system.

On the detail that Senator Quirke has asked—and Senator Quirke does ask sensible questions as a general rule—I suspect that he is talking about the opening of the building and not the turning of the first sod.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, while you are taking those bits on notice, can I give you a couple more? Did the money actually go to purchasing a solid gold shovel? Is Burson-Marstellar, who was paid $25,000 for this ceremony, the same firm that received an extremely lucrative public relations contract for the gun buyback through political favouritism and links with the Liberal Party?

—You are not good at those sorts of questions, Senator Quirke. Try asking a more serious question. In relation to the turning of the sod, I used a chrome-plated shovel which was made in Australia. Politics being what it is and in very unusual circumstances, two years later the same person who turned the sod opened the building. They actually gave me the shovel.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the furore over Australia's bid to have Hobart become the Antarctic Treaty System Secretariat headquarters. It is in competition, as you know, with bids from Argentina, Chile, New Zealand and elsewhere, and the matter will be determined in Oslo in May. The problem is that the Australian government has said that it will not allow for the usual tax deductibility of wages and so on and will expect the Tasmanian government to pay that cost, which would be up to $700,000. All political parties in Tasmania are united with the business community in calling on the federal government to change that position, which is going to be very damaging to Australia's bid when it comes to Oslo. I ask the minister: has the federal government changed that position? (Time expired)
—I am of course aware of the issue.
—Don't read your brief.
—Without reading the brief.
—Close your book.
—I am quite aware of the issue of the location of the secretariat—thank you, Senator Cook—and the sensitivity of the issue, in particular the matters between Britain and Argentina.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! A certain amount of levity is fine but we need to be able to hear the answer.

—We are very familiar with the matters between Britain and Argentina. The taxation matter that has been raised—I think I read about it when I was reading yesterday's Mercury —is incorrect in that, as I understand it, there is no circumstance being created that is unique for Tasmania. It is all hypothetical, of course, because we do not have the site of the secretariat. But if we were successful in doing so, the same rules would apply for Tasmania as apply to similar international organisations elsewhere in Australia.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer but I would like to make that absolutely explicit. Is the minister saying that therefore the headquarters in Hobart would get the same taxation exemption facility that is usually applied to headquarters of secretariats under international treaties? Secondly, the minister mentioned the matter of Britain and Argentina. There is a report in today's press that says that the Australian government is lukewarm because it is waiting to see what Britain does and may go in behind the Argentinian bid. Will the minister scotch such rumours by informing the Senate that the government is wholeheartedly behind the Australian bid to have this headquarters in Hobart and make that clear well and truly before the Oslo meeting in May?

—The honourable senator would know that the position of the previous Labor government was to support Buenos Aires rather than Hobart. I guess that is not surprising; that is what you would expect from Labor. We took a decision rather to pursue Australia's national interest. That is the process that is taking place at the moment and ultimately will be determined.

answer.para: We are quite proud of the role that Hobart plays as a gateway to the Antarctic, its role in relation to the CCAMLR treaty, its role in servicing our bases and its role in facilitating the service of other bases. It makes a very important contribution to the economy of Hobart as well as an important contribution to our overall national interest. In relation to the issue of tax exemptions, as I understand it, exactly the same rules will apply to Tasmania as apply to the rest of Australia.

Senator HERRON

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to questions without notice asked by Senators Lundy and Sherry today, relating to proposals to `outsource' services.

The whole issue of outsourcing of the Commonwealth government is one worthy of a great deal of scrutiny. Through the process of contracting out, a whole series of legal issues is raised about the consumers' ability to access remedies if they do not receive an adequate service or if they require some legal remedy. All of these issues were raised quite succinctly in the Ombudsman's 1996-97 annual report. Since then a Senate committee inquiry has embarked on an exploration of those issues even further. Mission for Information Technology
Moving Forward

talk.start.para: —Far from spending too much time on this subject, parliament ought to be spending a lot more. The work done in this area by Senator Lundy and Senator Carr is not only to be praised, but it is to be emulated. That is made quite clear by the very thought of what parliament is all about. One of the fundamental tasks of parliament is to see how the taxpayer's dollar is spent.

speech.para: Again and again over the centuries, people have said, `Parliament should ensure that the executive spends the taxpayer's dollar and spends it right.' That is exactly what this motion is all about. That is exactly what Senator Lundy is doing today, and it is exactly what Senator Lundy and Senator Carr have been doing in estimates. That is clearly brought out in a report from the Industry Commission which was published on 24 January 1996, where the commission had this to say on page 81:
Using competitive tendering and contracting (CTC) as a tool to achieve its various objectives more efficiently and effectively involves some fundamental—
and they use the word advisedly—
re-thinking of how government operates.
And indeed it does. The second last sentence of that paragraph, of which I have just read the first sentence, reads:
This raises questions about who is accountable, to whom, and for what.
The last sentence reads:
For some, the accountability-related issues such as privacy and discretion are so critical for some public services as to render them unsuitable for CTC.

As has been said in the chamber today, of course the actual money that may or may not be saved is important. But the more fundamental question, for us as a Senate and as part of the parliament, is to have the machinery available whereby we can properly supervise what the executive is doing. I intend to move a motion later on which asks these questions.

For example, when a government engages a consultant or when it outsources, it should inform the Senate that it has done so, it should state who the consultant is, it should identify the areas of the consultant's learning, it should set out the consultant's qualifications and it should tell the Senate what fee is paid to the consultant. That is machinery which would enable this chamber to see how government spends money.

If the money is spent by the Public Service itself—if it is not outsourced—then all those facilities are available to this chamber to ascertain whether it is a wise spending of money that has occurred. Once you outsource, questions of commercial confidentiality are legitimately raised, and of course private companies do not want to let out their secrets. But it does mean that the people who want to know how we, as a parliament—as an executive—are spending their dollars are denied the facility that they have when the matter is carried out by public servants.

The issue of privacy is this: the only way privacy is going to be protected is through the contractual relationship that is set up between the government and the person who is carrying out the outsourcing. Who can enforce that contract? Can the ordinary civilian enforce that contract? Probably not. Even if he or she could enforce that contract, the amount of money involved would be prohibitive. That is what we are talking about today: how can that fundamental duty of parliament to supervise the executive be carried out when the functions that have been performed by the executive are being contracted out?

talk.start.para: —A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex-servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex-members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex-members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex-members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex-members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL 1997 [No. 2]

Upon election, amending the Native Title Act 1993 to make it workable was one of the government's top priorities. After a period of consultation the Native Title Amendment Bill 1996 was introduced into the Parliament in June 1996. Before the amendments were debated, the Wik decision was handed down by the High Court on 23 December 1996.

The decision held that native title was capable of coexisting on pastoral leases, reversing a widely held presumption when the Act was passed in 1993. The Wik decision has led to intense public debate and uncertainty in rural areas about what activities pastoralists can currently perform on their leases. There are real difficulties with proceeding with pastoral business in some jurisdictions and consequent pressures on the government to provide certainty for government granted interests on all forms of tenure where native title coexistence is possible.

A replacement Bill incorporating the Government's response to the Wik decision was introduced on 4 September 1997 and passed by the House of Representatives in late October. After consideration by the Senate, the House laid the Bill aside on 6 December 1997 after indicating that some Senate amendments were not acceptable.

The Treasury and resources and farming/pastoral industry associations have indicated that there is a need for a response as soon as possible to the issues raised by the Wik decision. If not, uncertainty may reduce and delay investment in mining, petroleum and rural industries and, consequently, slow the rate of economic growth.
(Circulated by authority of the Prime Minister, the Hon John Howard, MP)
