talk.start.para: —I wish to comment tonight on the government's work for the dole program. As honourable senators would know, the program has recently got off the ground. Perhaps, predictably, if sadly, the initiative has been subjected to both unwarranted and ill-informed attack by Labor and others that has gone on since Christmas. The regrettable feature of this sort of attack is that it really fails to grasp the enormity of the problem of youth unemployment. It fails to recognise the value of an initiative that will have a number of good outcomes, including providing a pathway to job readiness.

speech.para: The criticisms suggest that Labor has simply forgotten that during 13 years in the job they failed to provide employment for almost one million Australians. In December 1992, at the height of the recession we had to have, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose to an historical high of 11.2 per cent. In trend terms, long-term unemployment reached an historical and unacceptable peak of 349,000 in July 1993.

Labor's record on youth unemployment was such that the number of young people with full-time jobs halved during its time in office. Full-time youth unemployment fell by approximately 240,000 from 465,000 in June 1989 to 227,600 in March 1994. Despite all this, the Labor Party took the opportunity during the summer recess to launch a scathing criticism of the government's work for the dole project. Such selective memories, I say.

Whilst it can be a dubious tactic to counter statistics with yet other statistics, it is imperative that some sense be made of the participation rates in the work for the dole scheme so that the doomsayers do not gain any credence in these sorts of attacks. Earlier this year it is true that the government was called upon to defend the scheme which at the time involved 869 volunteers and 574 conscripted participants in 62 pilot projects across the nation. Before enthusiasts go rushing for their calcu lators, the ratio of voluntary versus conscripted participants was 60 to 40. Surely even Labor would contend that only six weeks after the scheme was officially launched, participation in terms of size and composition could be considered an adequate or reliable indication or measure of the scheme's relative success or failure.

Still in its embryonic and formative stages, only one-third of the pilot projects had commenced—62 out of 178—involving 1,443 participants out of a total of 10,400 participants. Yet despite attacks on the scheme, the evidence is now coming through that it is actually working. One project—the historic Walka Waterworks near Newcastle—has already seen four young people find full-time employment, which is very good news indeed. This project only began in mid-January, so we have the situation of four young people already finding jobs only weeks into the project simply because they put their hands up and said they wanted to be in it.

The enthusiasm on this project shows how wrong Labor is. The project coordinator has reported that the young people are so keen that they are turning up to work on days they are not rostered to be there. Such motivation and keenness shows employers that these young people, despite often having been unemployed for long periods, are willing to work, want to work and certainly will work hard. One young man on the project—Paul Chamberlain—said that working on the project had boosted his confidence. He said, `You feel better about yourself. You're motivated to get up and go to work. You have something to do.' And all this from a scheme that the doomsayers say cannot work.

It is important when looking at the scheme to examine participation rates in their true light. The participation rate of each project does not actually reflect the fact that many are staggering their intake over 12 months. For example, a much quoted project in Bankstown has 47 participants out of a total of 96 places. I am using these examples from New South Wales, which of course is my home state. This figure can be interpreted in two ways. First, it could indicate that only half of the projects' positions have been filled, which in turn could lead to the assumption that there is little interest in the project, and used to sustain the myth that the work for the dole scheme is flawed. Or, second, and accurately as it turns out in this case, the project will offer a total of 96 positions throughout the year consisting of two, six-monthly intakes of 48 participants. Contrary to the gloom and doom interpretation, the project is operating at full capacity.

Past projects have shown that many participants are keen to contribute more than the hours required. Lisa Clausen, a journalist for the South Pacific, recalls how when funding from a project to build a skatebowl and basketball court in Sanctuary Point south of Sydney ran out, the 10 unemployed volunteers returned to the work site to finish the job in their own time. Eight of the 10 had found jobs within two months of completing the project.

The pilot programs are under way now and at present there are, as I said, 10,400 participants involved. When the scheme gets under way in full force, 25,000 places will be available, which the government has calculated as being sufficient to provide unemployed youth with work experience. It must be said that, on balance, not all projects will be successful—I think we have to say that—and projects will vary in their capacity to deliver outcomes.

Participation rates will depend upon a range of factors, including the nature of the project, the type of work involved, key personalities and project administration. Teething problems in a preliminary stage, however, cannot and do not reflect the scheme's outcomes. Some of the more intangible outcomes of the scheme, such as increased confidence and self-esteem, self-worth, networking opportunities and skills development, are not going to happen overnight. Indeed, a Labor funded community research project in 1995-96 concluded that 12 months was simply insufficient time for many projects to clearly define their roles, identify and engage target groups, and develop to full capacity.

In those circumstances, the opposition's call for an independent review of the scheme is wildly premature, and ACOSS's description of it as fundamentally flawed is defeatist. They complain that the scheme does not offer structured training. The answer to this critique is blindingly obvious. If a person has been unemployed since leaving school, he or she will not have any work experience and have few employment skills other than those they got at school. The scheme is designed to address that. It gives participants skills and experience that can be translated into their search for full-time employment. It does not offer structured training; nor does it pretend to. On the contrary, the scheme aims to have young unemployed people made ready for full-time employment as soon as possible. It is not providing a safety cocoon that discourages full-time employment. It is simply a starting block in the race for jobs.

If the labour market training programs of the former Labor government were so successful, one might ask rhetorically: how is it they produced record levels of youth unemployment? When the government took office in 1996 it was confronted with a situation that simply could not be allowed to continue and was created by years of neglect that saw the teenage full-time unemployment trend rate at 29 per cent. In some regional areas youth unemployment was as high as 30 per cent.

The government decided, rightly in my view, that this was an unacceptable situation for both the unemployed and the nation. But, unlike those who have for so long not provided any solutions, we did not push the issue into the too-hard basket and, having acted decisively, we are now reaping some benefits. The government's intention is to pilot new methods of solving youth unemployment. There is a glaring need to find new and innovative ways to break benefit dependency and to get our young people into employment.

The government has now committed $340 million over four years for its work for the dole, or mutual obligation, strategy. The background to the scheme is simply based on the premise that unemployed job seekers financially supported by the community should actively seek work. Some of the early results show that not only are they seeking to participate but they are getting jobs from that work experience.

talk.start.para: —In the Australian in the last two days reference has been made to very unacceptable practices by the army, especially at Holsworthy. In response to those the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop) held a press conference yesterday. During that press conference, as she tried to distance herself from the issue, on three separate occasions she stated, `And I would like to know whether or not either ministers of the day, Senators Ray and Faulkner, and particularly Mr Bevis, who was parliamentary secretary from 1994 through to the election, ever knew.'

speech.para: Let me put it on the record: we certainly did not know. No-one had reported that to us. If Mrs Bishop had bothered to even read the Australian article she would have found that article said no-one prior to June 1997 above the rank of Lieutenant Colonel knew of these practices. She would have known from that. She could have equally known from the current CDF, who was VCDF at the time, or the current head of the army, General Sanderson, who was also head of the army when I was minister, or General Baker as CDF because she surely would have asked them whether this had ever come up before and they surely would have said no.

So what leads this minister to ask this question rhetorically three times in a row? The only answer for that is absolute crass political opportunism. The only answer to that is she is trying to shift the blame—and I will accept some responsibility for any practices that occurred in Defence when I was minister, but it is hard to do anything about them if no-one ever told you about them. I challenge Mrs Bishop to find in the defence department one piece of advice on this issue to me, Mr Punch, Mr Bevis or Senator Faulkner. I also challenge her to find one piece of correspondence that was ever written to any of the four of us complaining about these particular practices.

Everyone knows that, if I had found out about it, it would have ceased that day. I would have come down on them like a ton of bricks, as I did with the sexual harassers, whom we came down on like a ton of bricks the moment we found out about them. Instead, we have a minister obviously with no dignity, no courage and no principle coming out and asking these questions, to which she already knows the answer. She already knows that the previous government was not informed.

If she wants a clue to that, why doesn't she ask the army why, when the upper echelon discovered this in June 1997, she did not find out about this until 11 February 1998? It is because they did not tell her. Because they wanted to clean up their own mess, they refused to pass it down the line like they should have, exactly like when the lieutenant colonels and others when I and Senator Faulkner were the responsible minister would not have passed it up the line. So the answer is all there.

What we get from Mrs Bishop is a political statement—cheap, crass and lacking the dignity of the office she holds. An office in the defence area does carry a little more dignity than some of the more robust political portfolios. So what is her excuse for operating like a third-rate ward heeler? Simple lack of political courage, simple lack of saying yes, this is a problem and it was a problem under the previous government undiscovered and a problem under this government undiscovered and, once it was discovered, appropriate action was taken.

But what action does she take? She sets up a departmental inquiry. What action did we take in response to the sexual harassment claims. We sent that to a Senate committee—it was me who referred it—for a full inquiry in the public gaze, taking all the risks incumbent on that course of action in what may come out of that Senate inquiry.

I have been silent on defence issues for two years. I hope I can be silent on them again for the next 10 years. I do not believe, having held a portfolio, that you go back and dog the previous minister all the time; that you chase them down every burrow and criticise them. They have a job to do. Let them get on and do it. I wish them well and I hope they do it well. But, with this sort of attitude from Mrs Bishop, if she wants to get me back on the lists, if she wants to get me at an estimates committee for five days in a row, then I will accommodate her. But I do not think her colleagues would be too happy with that.

This is good group therapy for me tonight, obviously. Let me move to a second issue, and that is Senator Minchin's press release of 5 March. He is commenting on the issue of travel allowance for members of parliament. I must say that I thought the Remuneration Tribunal produced a good report and a sensible report. It does not matter, Madam President. It does not matter what rules they devise, I can tell you now that no-one is going to cheat. It does not matter if you have the loosest rules in the world. After what happened last year, no-one—I cannot even accuse my worst enemy in the parliament—is going to be dumb enough to cheat on travel allowance again; they are just not. Nevertheless, the tribunal has come up with a set of very sensible rules, and I endorse them all. There was logic and good thought behind them.

But Senator Minchin, in his hyperbole in the press release, goes on to take credit for all of this. It is actually the Remuneration Tribunal. In part of it he says, `Something the Labor Party were incapable of achieving during their 13 years of government.' He is talking about the new travel allowance arrangements. As I recall it, the first government to publish expenses was the Labor government of 1983. They were never published before that. The Hawke government in its first year published all figures as to ministerial and office holders' travel allowance, to their Commonwealth car cost, to their overseas trips. It also published the cost of staff travel allowance and staff Commonwealth car and transport costs. That was the first one ever. Action was taken there because these things are best dealt with in the end not by rules, not by prosecution but by transparency. There is no acknowledgment of it here.

Who was the first person to authorise the full exposure of senators' travel allowance? Let us face it: once that was done, it cleaned up the whole system. The answer is that the former President of the Senate, Michael Beahan, made the decision. Who was gracious and intelligent enough to implement this scheme? The incumbent in the chair tonight was sensible enough to enforce Beahan's in-principle decision and put it into practice. So, if you are looking for why the whole area of travel allowance was cleaned up, it was basically by two presiding officers in this parliament. Once you put all the details down and made it transparent, anyone that was rorting the system became pretty obvious. Therefore they could clean up the system.

For Senator Minchin to say that they have done everything belies two points. When Mr Andren, an Independent member in the House of Representatives, moved for a similar publication in the House of Representatives, all he did was get stalled for six weeks. It was only in the panic after 8 April, when certain events occurred, that suddenly it became clear water. The coalition agreed to the publication of those figures under intense pressure.

Let me say one other thing on this. I am sick of hearing how this government claim they were the ones responsible for cleaning up parliamentary entitlements. Yes, they did in the end; they did it under pressure. But the old department of DAS consistently pressured former Minister Jull—and I must say responded well—in September 1996 for a full reform of this system. They authorised Mr Sam Skrzypek, who was not in the ministerial and parliamentary services area, to do a paper on this particular thing. They then developed a policy submission on the reform of parliamentary entitlements. They had several meetings in January 1997, properly minuted, progressing this issue. They incorporated it in a submission to the Expenditure Review Committee. They put it in a second submission to the Expenditure Review Committee.

But they also made a decision then, as the minutes record, to go out and test the waters on this—that is, slip around to Mr Reith's office and Mr Howard's office and say, `Is this okay? Are we able to do this?' Guess what? On 5 February 1997 all references to a review of parliamentary entitlements went out the window. They got deleted completely out of the submission. The word back to Mr Jull's office was, `Don't rock the boat. Everything is fine.' So this great reforming government deliberately junked it on 5 February!

Sure, they reinstituted it all on 5 March. Why? Because certain matters associated that may be in the courts in the future, so I will not go to the specifics, were raised. Mr Jull, as the then minister, panicked. Half an hour before question time he made a decision to have a review. He rang his department and said, `I want KPMG and Baxter to do the review.' He then rang Mr Baxter. Twenty-five minutes before question time, he said, `I want you to do the review. We will settle the details later,' which was months later. So any pretence that this government was serious about this issue until the liquid matter hit the fan is absolutely denied. It is there in the records of DoF and the former DAS for anyone that wants to see it, if the government will ever release the papers.

talk.start.para: —As the Senate will be aware, the government set aside $4½ million to be spent on research and public information about electromagnetic radiation. There are two matters that I wish to raise tonight: one is the question of accountability and how this money is to be spent; and the other is an article which was published in the Australian today by Stewart Fist on the study into exposure to power lines.

speech.para: Both these matters go to the question of public confidence in the outcome of research. The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts handed responsibility for deciding which research projects would be given grants from the $4½ million to the NHMRC last year. The NHMRC set up an expert committee to do this, which, as I understand it, will shortly announce which studies will accept the offers that were made. That will be a matter for the public to see.

Now of course it makes sense for the NHMRC to do this work. It is at arm's length from government. But the problem is that the committee was also supposed to be at arm's length from the telecommunications industry. It is hardly surprising that people such as me are sceptical about the fact that Dr Ken Joyner, a scientist who is and has been employed by Motorola for some years, is on that committee.

I make no judgments about the work of Dr Joyner. I am sure that his qualifications and his experience are as good as anyone's in this country—in fact, I have heard that said by a number of people. The problem simply is that he has a vested interest in discovering that electromagnetic radiation has no effects on health. Whether his judgment about which research project should go ahead is affected by this association with the industry or not, the NHMRC cannot demonstrate that his influence and his decisions are totally impartial. Given the controversy which surrounds this issue, in my view, the committee must be and must be seen to be at arm's length from industry.

The Senate will recall that a year ago the results of a study conducted for Telstra by the Royal Adelaide Hospital were released. It showed that exposure to digital cellular phone radiation doubled the immune cell cancers in transgenic mice. You may also recall that the industry shrugged this off saying that the results had no implications for humans. The minister, whom you would expect to be interested in the health of the nation, made a joke of the whole thing, advising that mice should desist from using mobile phones.

The second part of that study was released last week—this time into health dangers associated with electrical power lines, commissioned by the Electricity Supply Association. I cannot improve on Mr Fist's article, so I will quote from him extensively. He explains:
The 50Hz study was conducted by the same team, used the same transgenic mice housed under the same environmental and handling conditions, as the GSM study.
The only real difference was that they had five groups of 100 mice . . . which were exposed to pseudo-mains power at different levels of magnetic flux.

This is called pseudo-mains power because the research design specifically filtered out all radio-frequency type electromagnetic pollu tants, which we experience daily when we use electrical devices. The article continues:
This was done to expose the mice to a clean, 50-cycle magnetic field. . . .
There is nothing sinister about this filtering—
it just allows scientists to test for each factor independently—
However, the problem this protocol generates is that the results cannot then be extrapolated to normal human experience with mains power.
Mr Fist says that this is one reason why the media is overstating the research findings of this study as being safe—as they did last week. He goes on:

There's another minor problem here. In the near-field (within a distance of one wavelength) there are both magnetic and electrical fields, and this experiment was really only designed to look at the magnetic field.
There are no figures given for electrical measurements.
The power lines-are-safe conclusion isn't strongly supported by the published report itself either—which is not at all uncommon in power-line research.
Reports published in the newspapers constantly confuse "no evidence" with "evidence of no effect".

Others include nonsense such as: "Hundreds of studies have failed to prove . . . " when most of the studies set out to prove something different or to disprove a hypothesis that may have little direct bearing on the area of concern.
Last July, for instance, a story circulated around the world that a US National Cancer Institute study had proved high-tension power lines didn't produce childhood leukaemia.
Closer examination of the published data showed the exact opposite.
The NCI study collected evidence of the incidence of leukaemia among children living near high-tension power lines, and it used as an arbitrary cut-off point 2mG (micro-Gauss) of field strength.

Usually, 3mG is the figure used in this work, and when the statistics for these more highly exposed kids were included the increase in leukaemia was statistically significant—with almost twice the expected number of cases.

There are dozens of similar epidemiological studies from various countries, most of which reveal a small but significant link with leukaemia for children living close to high-tension power lines. A few don't, and a few laboratory studies are also ambiguous or dismissive.
So while nothing is proven, there's enough hard evidence here to worry government authorities and power companies despite the barrage of public relations distortions from the electricity industry.
This is the background against which the ESAA's research was conducted.
The researchers had five groups of mice, each with about 100 lymphoma- prone rodents . . .
One group received identical treatment to the others but had no magnetic field exposure . . .
The four exposed groups received 50Hz magnetic fields doses of different levels for 20 hours daily, using specially-built . . . coils around their cages.
One group received a tiny dose . . . at a level experienced only by most people for a short part of the day.
Another received 100 times that dose, and two other groups were exposed at 1000 times.
One of the high exposure groups received its dose in on-off cycles of 15 minute intervals, but with transients suppressed.
In this type of research the scientists are not remotely interested in the sheer number of cancers developed by the mice because they've chosen special cancer-prone mice.
They anticipate 15 per cent of the mice will spontaneously develop lymphomas within 18 months anyway.
The point is that they are using these mice as sensitive detectors to see if the 50Hz fields make a difference to the cancer rate.
Ultimately, they are only interested in the possibility of humans developing cancers over a lifetime, so the cancer-prone mice over 18 months are a sort of proxy for humans over 80 years.
It's the ratio between the sham (unexposed group) and those receiving the high doses of magnetic fields that is the key, not the absolute numbers.
The in-between groups should also show some grading if the problems are dose-related.
These figures aren't always easy to interpret.
For instance, many of the heavily exposed mice died of renal problems.
Should the researchers count these or not? This kidney disease could be the result of pure chance, or it could be a new and unknown 50Hz effect.
If it did arise by chance, it will almost certainly have masked real cancer conditions in some of the mice. But how many?
If a mouse dies of kidney disease or unknown causes early in the experiment, who is to know whether it would have developed lymphoma?
This introduces uncertainty. These are the complications that scientists try to express to the public in the form of a simple expression of significance.
A 5 per cent level of significance means the results could have arisen one time in 20 by chance; a 1 per cent level is more convincing, since it could only arise once in 100 similar experiments.
In this study, the researchers found the significance levels too low to be conclusive.
The mice receiving the higher magnetic doses developed more lymphomas, but also more renal problems by a considerable margin. So conclusions couldn't be drawn.
Madam President, I have a couple more minutes to read and I am obviously going to run out of time. I seek leave to incorporate the remaining parts of this article in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The article read as follows—
The most disturbing finding they made, I think, is that there is extreme variation in the number of spontaneous tumours in the unexposed control groups.

You wouldn't expect variability of this order. The power line sham group had nearly a third more lymphomas than the GSM shams, and nearly double the rate previously experienced with this strain of mice.

This suggests that the higher-than-expected incidence of lymphoma in the unexposed group could easily have masked a real change resulting from mains power, since the significance of the exposure is always calculated from the sham mice's spontaneous rate.
In other words, it partly destroys the validity of the whole exercise. To make this clear by analogy: what the research is measuring is the apparent height of a mountain (a variation from normal).
Research always measures from the base (the control group's spontaneous levels).

However, if that base is revealed to be a cloud layer already well above the surrounding plain (through chance elevation or some unknown environmental factor) the measurements make the mountain look less impressive than it really is.
Beneath the cloud the mountain may be substantial, but we have no real way of knowing.
So, despite the published news stories, I don't read the report as giving either the pure 50Hz magnetic fields or the power lines a clean bill of health.
Paradoxically, the study draws a new perspective on the earlier R/F study. It reinforced our cell- phone fears, because none of these mice showed basal cell (b-cell) lymphomas.
In the cell-phone study the b-cell lymphoma incidence was a new and unexpected finding.

So the b-cell finding is now associated only with cell-phone exposure, and not with the mouse strain, which destroys any remnants of credibility that might remain about setting Australia's exposure standards on the basis only of increases in tissue temperature.

talk.start.para: —I will just finish with the final paragraph which is important. Mr Fist says:

speech.para: Scientists and politicians cannot have it both ways. They cannot treat this study as proving powerline safety for humans but dismiss the other as just applying to mice.

talk.start.para: —The defining nature of our democracy is freedom of speech. No matter what your beliefs, whether you support or oppose the government of the day, you will be heard. But not so anymore. A small group in the left of the Labor Party are despicably changing the face of our democracy. They have used their mate Peter Yu in the National Indigenous Working Group to gag Father Frank Brennan.
—It's sickening.

—It is the truth. Alan Ramsey brought it to light two weeks ago. So important was this issue that he wrote about it the following week, and I bring it to the attention of the Senate tonight. Brennan has been gagged because he is a threat to Labor's divisive politics. Gareth Evans on radio on 2 March said that Frank had not been muzzled, but Brennan tells a different story. It is all on the record. In a letter to Ron Castan, the prominent Melbourne QC and key adviser and strategist for the ALP and the National Indigenous Working Group on 5 March, and reported by Ramsey on 7 March, Brennan wrote:

speech.para: Outsiders like myself could have brought some pressure to bear on government to deal with indigenous leaders. But you and the whole delegation who visited me on 14 January were anxious I remain silent, given my `unorthodox' views on the Racial Discrimination Act.
Father Brennan's letter shows clearly that Gareth Evans has read Richo's book Whatever It Takes .

The strange thing, however, is that Brennan is only arguing what the Labor Party argued in 1993. Labor then argued that to make the Wik legislation subservient to the Racial Discrimination Act would create legal chaos. In an article published in Eureka Street in January this year Father Brennan wrote:

If the Labor Party faced up to the real world now, they would realise that it [making the legislation subject to the RDA] would be, and is, not an appropriate thing to do if you want to have the legislation work for the benefit of indigenous people—native title holders—and in fairness to the right of other persons. Despite the populist appeal of this amendment, the Opposition parties should back down in the interests of certainty, justice and workability for all stakeholders.
No wonder Labor has told Father Brennan to shut up.

On page 25 of the majority report by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs into the Native Title Bill 1993, Labor's Senator Cooney, Senator Chris Evans and Senate McKiernan specifically recommended that the Native Title Act `should not be subject to the Racial Discrimination Act because of the uncertainty that this would create'. I repeat, should not be subject to the RDA. Gareth Evans argued in this place at the time, and I quote from the Hansard of 17 December 1993:

The concern is that if we overemphasised the specific need for continued consistency with the Racial Discrimination Act perhaps that might somehow be put at risk, or other unforeseen consequences may arise.

There has never been any doubt about our good faith in wanting the Racial Discrimination Act to apply. We have just been concerned about possible unforeseen technical consequences flowing from its application.

The Keating government accepted the committee's recommendation. Four years later Labor is supporting an amendment which they were not prepared to pursue when they were in government. This is an irresponsible opposition. So what we have now is an opposition feeling threatened by a Jesuit priest and being backed into a corner by their own looney left and the National Indigenous Working Group.

Father Brennan is not the only one who the likes of Peter Yu and Noel Pearson have attempted to silence. There is a greater enemy to the Aboriginal industry. That enemy, feared by Yu, Pearson, Dodson and others, is Aboriginals themselves. I have visited many outback Aboriginal committees, often with the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, and on occasion after occasion Aboriginals tell me that the Pearsons and Yus do not speak for them.

talk.start.para: —Is that when Herron gave you this speech?

—I am good enough to write my own speeches, Kim. Ask Mick Mundine at Redfern what he thinks. I once asked Peter Yu in Broome what he was doing for the people at Noonkanbah to ensure they could educate their children and they could save some money for their children just like he was. His answer astonished me. He said, `I have never thought about it.'

speech.para: What the majority of Aboriginals and pastoralists alike want is certainty and equity. The existing act does not provide this. This is detailed by ATSIC's own admission in its report State of the nation: Report on native title outcomes. To date, there are over 700 applications for native title determination over about half of Australia. Only two claims have been determined. The coalition amendments offer all Australians certainty. We do not discriminate over colour. Labor, on the other hand, insists that the right to negotiate apply on pastoral leases. This is discriminatory to farmers like me by guaranteeing to native title claimants a set of rights not available to Australian farmers. Labor would support this type of discrimination, yet insists that the whole act be subject to the Racial Discrimination Act. Labor's logic is mind-boggling.

Recently, my attention was brought to a letter which appeared in the West Australian written by a Mr Rivers. I urge all senators on the other side of this chamber to listen carefully to what Mr Rivers had to say and to think long and hard as to what their obstruction of the government's amendments is doing to the reconciliation process and the progress of the majority of Aboriginals. More people in the media should be telling Mr Rivers' story and the stories of others like him. Others like him are sick and tired of being ignored. The silence in the media over the majority of Aboriginal thinking is as bad as the ALP's gagging of Father Frank Brennan. Rivers wrote:

I am an Aboriginal from the East Kimberley in Western Australia. I with many other Aboriginal people in the East Kimberley, am becoming very upset that the media, churches and political and community leaders seem to think that the likes of Pat Dodson, Noel Pearson, Peter Yu and Louis O'Donoghue are the leaders of the Aboriginal people and speak for the Aboriginal people in Australia.
They may speak for the Aboriginal industry and its various hangers-on, such as the do-gooders and greenies, but they don't speak for Aboriginal people.
These so called leaders have driven a wedge between the Aboriginal people and the wider Australian community because it suits their purposes.
It seems that none of these co-called leaders has done anything conciliatory. Reconciliation is a two-way thing.
An Aboriginal wrote that from the Kimberley.

Labor has learnt well from their mate, `Whatever it takes' Richardson—to lie and defy their own position as a government in 1993, a position which reflected the present position of the now silenced adviser to the native title indigenous working group, Father Brennan, and the advice of his father, Chief Justice Brennan, in his Wik determination. That position, of course, is the government's. This government is opposed to making the Wik legislation subject to the RDA. Father Brennan said it all when he said:

I am sufficiently respectful of Aboriginal self-determination that, when key Aboriginal leaders such as the NIWG seek my silence, then of course it must be given, even though I have the gravest fears their decision is one that will do irreparable harm to Aboriginal interests . . .
Ramsey pointed out that `Father Brennan's measured words are bullets.' As Ramsey's Labor leaker concluded:

What you've got is Labor locked into something in opposition which it could never bring itself to do in government. Yet basically, the NIWG think Labor is still in Government, and given that Labor is not in Government, they think they can go down some looney path and get a double dissolution that will get Labor elected.

That is the Labor Party itself speaking. By adopting this totally irresponsible strategy, which includes silencing any criticism from the honest brokers—McKiernan and Cooney et cetera, in your own report—

talk.start.para: —Senator, address the senators properly.

—Thank you, Madam President. By silencing criticism from within their own ranks, by ignoring the pleas of the `non-industry' indigenous and turning a deaf ear to the concerns of spurious native title claims raised by ATSIC, Labor is plunging Australia's land title system into chaos. Alan Ramsey has totally destroyed the credibility of the National Indigenous Working Group and Labor. I would have loved to have been a fly on the wall as the rats rang in to abuse Mr Ramsey.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Force Personnel: Service in Thailand
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1062)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 January 1998:

question.para: Were any Australian troops involved in the construction of an airstrip near the town of Leong Nok Tha in north east Thailand during the years 1965 to 1968; if so, who was the airstrip ultimately used by and for what purpose.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Departmental records indicate that the 2nd Troop of the 1st Field Squadron, Royal Australian Engineers undertook the construction of a concrete runway in North East Thailand in conjunction with the 11th Independent Squadron, Royal Engineers (Malaysia), as part of Operation Crown. This operation, which lasted 6 months, commenced in December 1965 and was carried out under the auspices of the South East Asian Treaty Organisation (SEATO).
There is nothing available in departmental records to indicate by whom the airstrip was ultimately used and for what purpose.
